Comment: If I was one of the major platforms, I'd say let them do it and we'll just cut off service to Texas. The porn sites did, and somehow Pornhub hasn't gone out of business yet - and they cut off service to what, Texas, Florida, and Utah? If the Porn industry can take the hit and not blink than somehow I think the social media industry can with even less concern. At that point you don't even have to worry about enforcement  Edit for addition: I mean really, think about it. If you are on a YouTube video, which is definitely social media owned by Google, what ads do you see? If you're not like me where I have pretty much everything blocked, you're seeing local ads. So who is that going to hurt? Texas businesses. Texas is a large state, but think about Google and YouTube's overall reach. When you are considering it on that scope, 38 million people is pretty small potatoes. Yes there's some fairly well-known YouTubers down here. Nexpo, Oompaville, and Coffeezilla to name a few. You want to tell me that they won't still be able to upload content? Their business doesn't require it to be uploaded from Texas, even if it's created here. In the digital world those borders aren't exactly restrictive. In addition to that, as I originally mentioned, it isn't exactly difficult to skirt any block that YouTube, facebook, reddit, or any other service puts on access to their sites. After all it only has to be a cursory block, they don't have to put any real effort into it. Just block anything geolocated to Texas and call it a fucking day. Their users will find their way back to them by whatever method. Only Texas loses.
